name: Cougar Creek
description:
Introduction

A canyon with lots of variety. Big pools and jumps, long free hanging rappels. A convenient car shuttle.

The water flow will increase as you go though the canyon. Flow is probably 3-4x at the end of the narrows than where you drop in.

This is not a well outfitted and commonly run canyon, folks should be prepared to rebuild anchors.

Approach

Drive on the paved road past Ape Cave. Turn on to a dirt forest road at 46.12382, -122.24213 and drive down this until the creek has washed out the road (the drop in point). Your vehicle probably won't make it all the way, a RAV4 made it to 0.6 miles away from the drop in point.

An untested, but possibly better approach could be to drive on the paved road until 46.12456, -122.26307, then drop into the creek at 46.12453, -122.25921. It looks like this could add a rappel too.

Descent

The opening

1. 40ft rap from bolt DCL

2. 70ft rap from tree DCR

[A long brushy creek walk]

The fools waterpark

This section starts shortly after the confluence. It has many pools that look like jumps, but none of them go except the mandatory one. Scrambling around is generally easy, some more rappels could be added here for fun.

3. 40ft rap from bolt on large boulder center canyon

4. Mandatory 15ft jump

[more fools waterpark]

5. 130ft rap from tree DCR. This line will hit you with all the water right in the face as you go over the lip, the rest will be free hanging.

After this there is about 3000ft of bouldery creek-walking to the narrows.

The narrows

6. 25ft rap from bolt DCL

7. 8ft plunge, was downclimbed on log DCR

8. 3ft plunge out of slot, DONT JUMP (big boulders), lower yourself down

[confluence]

9. 20ft jump

10. log jam, ending with possible 15ft jump

11. 25ft jump

12. 35ft rap from bolt DCR. This is a bad line, would be deadly in higher flow. A different anchor should be created DCL.

Link to Visual Beta

Exit

After the last plunge pool continue walking down the creek, you will immediately pass a waterfall coming in on the right and the walls will start to widen and the creek will get shallower and sandy bottomed. Change out of your wetsuit. Navigate around the meadow on its left edge then head through the forest to the Trail of Two Forests parking lot where you left a car. This is mostly on the lava flow which is some up and down but brush does not grow on lava so it is easy walking.

Red tape

You will pass through the booth for Ape Cave and they will ask you if you have a reservation for that. Tell them you are going up the forest road to take pictures of the waterfall on Cougar Creek.

Beta sites

Trip reports and media

Background

Scouted by Eric Jorgenson on June 10, 2023. First descent by Eric Jorgenson, Amy Kolor and Lauren Kenyon on July 3, 2023.
